text:
Where can I find more info on the behavior of broadcast and the dimensions on arrays, i.e. explanation this behavior. I'm confident its in the manual but I cannot find it.
```x=rand(10)
x .+ x'```

elements.text: Where can I find more info on the behavior of broadcast and the dimensions on arrays, i.e. explanation this behavior. I'm confident its in the manual but I cannot find it.

x=rand(10)
x .+ x'
https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/arrays/#Broadcasting
and
https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/base/arrays/#Base.Broadcast.broadcast

text: Thanks, but I'm not seeing what I'm looking for. In this case broadcast is not simply "element-wise"

elements.text: Thanks, but I'm not seeing what I'm looking for. In this case broadcast is not simply "element-wise"

text: x is 10 by 1 and x' is 1 by 10 the result is 10 by 10.

elements.text: x is 10 by 1 and x' is 1 by 10 the result is 10 by 10.

text: X isn't actually 10x1, it's a length 10 vector. And x' is a length ten RowVector. If you try with rand(10,1) you'll get something else ;)

elements.text: X isn't actually 10x1, it's a length 10 vector. And x' is a length ten RowVector. If you try with rand(10,1) you'll get something else ;)
Related :
https://github.com/julialang/julia/issues/4774

text: Also I think <@U677NAWV8> has a Julia con talk from a few years ago on this, not sure if there's a video

elements.text: Also I think
has a Julia con talk from a few years ago on this, not sure if there's a video

text: you are absolutely correct. I was being loose with terms. I understand what the broadcast is doing and I understand why the result is 10x10. I use this frequently. I'm trying to explain it to somebody else and am struggling. I was hoping it was in the docs.  I'm trying to figure out the mechanism, logic of how the various dimensioning works, there is some "inner vs. outer" dim behavior.

elements.text: you are absolutely correct. I was being loose with terms. I understand what the broadcast is doing and I understand why the result is 10x10. I use this frequently. text: oh actually with a 10x1 matrix it still works, hm

elements.text: oh actually with a 10x1 matrix it still works, hm

text: I guess length-one dimensions get expanded

elements.text: I guess length-one dimensions get expanded

text:
Here's the section of the docs where this is explained:
<https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/arrays/#Broadcasting>

elements.text: Here's the section of the docs where this is explained:

text: The key passage for me was "Julia provides `broadcast`, which expands singleton dimensions in array arguments to match the corresponding dimension in the other array without using extra memory, and applies the given function elementwise"

elements.text: The key passage for me was "Julia provides
broadcast
, which expands singleton dimensions in array arguments to match the corresponding dimension in the other array without using extra memory, and applies the given function elementwise"

text: I guess "expands" could be expanded on a bit more to specify that the elements are (virtually) replicated in the expansion.

elements.text: I guess "expands" could be expanded on a bit more to specify that the elements are (virtually) replicated in the expansion.

text: ah... I think I was misinterpreting that passage. It makes sense now. Thank you!

elements.text: ah... I think I was misinterpreting that passage. It makes sense now. Thank you!
